The research itself isn’t, so long as it’s done correctly and hasn’t been subjected to things like p-hacking. However, the way the research is interpreted is somewhat subjective. For example, there is a correlation between high intelligence and a tendency to stay up and sleep in later than average. This in itself is not scientifically “biased”. However, different psychologists may make different inferences about the research. Some psychologists believe that smart people are likely to stay up and sleep in later because it’s an evolutionarily novel thing to do. That sort of interpretation is logical but somewhat subjective, other psychologists have different theories on the link.

Greetings Svetlana, The research itself is not biased if done properly, the conclusions however…Having studied human behavior through works having for methods psychoanalysis, psychology and behaviorism for twenty years and practicing for the last twenty years, I can assure you that in some cases, the solution or treatment had nothing to do with textbooks. In conclusion, if you do research with the purpose of examining behaviors ‘in a certain context’, then do so; but do not generalize; otherwise you will end up with the conclusion that Vladimir Putin sings like Feodor Chaliapin just because they are both Russian… In Peace and Friendship, Pierre

What you are suggesting is a much deeper problem. “Are psychological claims from experiments repeatable, and verifiable?”. This is a huge problem with the science of behaviour. Is it really empirical like the other hard sciences such as chemistry and physics? An article in “Psychology Today” magazine a few months ago went into this for a few pages. A surprising number are not. Psychological researchers who have looked into this have been singled out for ridicule by other psychologists because of the possible impact of their findings. Beware.
